summary: This is a reply memorandum filed by the Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) in a FOIA lawsuit brought by The New York Times Company. The BOP argues its withholdings of records related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and death are proper under various FOIA exemptions (7(A), 6, 7(C), 5, 7(E), 7(F)), citing interference with pending criminal cases (United States v. Tartaglione and United States v. Noel) and privacy interests. This is a legal memorandum filed by the government (likely the U.S. Department of Justice) in opposition to a FOIA request concerning Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and death. The document argues for the proper withholding of records under various FOIA exemptions (7(A), 6, 7(C), 5, 7(E)), citing ongoing criminal proceedings, privacy interests of Epstein's family and third parties, and the protection of law enforcement techniques and internal deliberations. This document is page 24-25 of a court filing (likely a reply brief) from the U.S. Department of Justice/Bureau of Prisons (BOP) in response to a FOIA lawsuit. It argues for withholding certain records under Exemption 7(E) of the FOIA, claiming the release of specific investigatory techniques used in response to a suicide attempt and suicide at a federal prison (likely MCC New York, where Jeffrey Epstein died) would compromise their effectiveness. The filing opposes the plaintiff's cross-motion for summary judgment.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: Signs off on the court filing as the Acting U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York, representing the defendant (the government/BOP).

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the FOIA request. The document discusses withholding details and images of his death, as well as records related to his incarceration and suicide at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC).

persons.name: Tartaglione
persons.context: A defendant in a pending federal death penalty prosecution (United States v. Tartaglione). The BOP argues release of records about Epstein's suicide attempt could interfere with this case, as Tartaglione's defense has placed his conditions of confinement and interactions with Epstein at issue.

persons.name: Michael Thomas
persons.context: A defendant in the criminal case 'United States v. Noel'. The document references a motion to compel filed by his defense and notes that some materials withheld in this FOIA case have been disclosed to him under a protective order.

persons.name: Tova Noel
persons.context: A defendant in a pending federal prosecution (United States v. Noel). The BOP argues release of records could interfere with this case, as they contain information about expected witnesses and details not publicly known.

persons.name: Noel
persons.context: A defendant in the criminal case 'United States v. Noel' (first name not provided in this excerpt). The government argues that disclosing records related to Epstein would interfere with this ongoing prosecution.

persons.name: Judge Torres
persons.context: A judge who issued a decision in the 'Noel' criminal case. The government argues this decision cuts against the FOIA plaintiff's position.

persons.name: Epstein's brother
persons.context: Referenced as having a privacy interest in preventing the public release of details and images of Jeffrey Epstein's death, as established by legal precedent.

persons.name: Doherty
persons.context: Cited as a plaintiff in a prior FOIA case (Doherty v. U.S. Dep't of Justice) which established legal precedent regarding Exemption 7(E).

persons.name: Allard K. Lowenstein
persons.context: Cited indirectly via the 'Allard K. Lowenstein Int'l Human Rights Project' case, which is referenced for legal precedent on FOIA Exemption 7(E).

connections.description: They were both inmates at the MCC. Tartaglione's defense has put his conditions of confinement and interactions with Epstein at issue in his criminal case.
As Acting U.S. Attorney, her office is representing the BOP (the defendant) in this FOIA lawsuit.
Epstein's brother is identified as a surviving family member with a recognized privacy interest in the details of Epstein's death.
Both are defendants in the same criminal case, 'United States v. Noel'.

events.title: Epstein's Apparent Suicide Attempt
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein's apparent suicide attempt while incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). This event prompted internal BOP deliberations about his housing and suicide prevention.

events.title: Epstein's Death by Suicide
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide while in BOP custody at the MCC. The circumstances prompted an investigation by the DOJ Office of the Inspector General (OIG).

events.title: BOP Files Motion for Summary Judgment
events.description: The Federal Bureau of Prisons filed its opening memorandum of law in support of its motion for summary judgment in this FOIA case.

events.title: BOP Produces Returned Records
events.description: BOP produced 190 pages of records to The New York Times, consisting of documents returned by the OIG after its investigation into Epstein's death.

events.title: Epstein's Suicide
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide via hanging in his cell at the MCC. This triggered multiple BOP investigations, including a psychological reconstruction and an After Action Review.

events.title: Government Letter in Noel Case
events.description: The government filed a letter in the 'United States v. Noel' case, referenced to show that materials related to Epstein had been disclosed to criminal defendants under a protective order.

events.title: FOIA Lawsuit and Summary Judgment Motions
events.description: Ongoing litigation where a plaintiff is seeking records under the Freedom of Information Act related to an incident at a Bureau of Prisons facility. The government (BOP) is moving for summary judgment to withhold records, and the plaintiff has filed a cross-motion.

events.title: Suicide Attempt and Suicide at BOP Facility
events.description: Referenced as the specific incident that triggered the BOP's investigatory techniques. The context strongly implies this refers to the events surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's death at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) - The federal jail in New York where Jeffrey Epstein was incarcerated and died.
Southern District of New York (S.D.N.Y.) - The federal court district where the related criminal case 'United States v. Noel' and this FOIA lawsuit are pending.
Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) (implied as the facility where the investigated incident occurred)
86 Chambers Street, Third Floor, New York, New York 10007 (Office of the U.S. Attorney)
keyFacts: The BOP is withholding records related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and death under FOIA Exemption 7(A), arguing disclosure could interfere with two pending federal criminal prosecutions: United States v. Tartaglione (a death penalty case) and United States v. Noel.
Withheld records include possible trial exhibits, information about expected witnesses, documents prepared by potential witnesses, and information about Epstein's apparent suicide attempt.

The BOP also invokes privacy exemptions (6 and 7(C)) to protect images of Epstein's body, details of his suicide, and the names of his associates, arguing his family and associates have a privacy interest.
Exemption 5 (deliberative process privilege) is invoked for predecisional discussions about where and how to house Epstein after his July 2019 suicide attempt and for draft documents.
The parties reached an agreement where the DOJ OIG returned investigative records to BOP for FOIA review, and BOP subsequently produced some and withheld others, including 387 pages withheld in full.
The government is vigorously opposing a FOIA request for records on Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and death, citing multiple exemptions to prevent disclosure.

A key argument is that disclosure would interfere with the ongoing criminal prosecution in 'United States v. Noel', as some of the withheld materials have been shared with those defendants under a protective order.

The government asserts a strong privacy interest for Epstein's brother and other third parties (visitors, callers, fund transferors) in not having their associations with Epstein officially confirmed or publicized by the BOP.

Withheld records include details and images of Epstein's death, internal BOP deliberations on his housing and suicide prevention, and specific law enforcement investigative techniques used after his suicide attempt.
The document reveals the existence of a BOP 'psychological reconstruction' report and an 'After Action Review Team' report related to Epstein's suicide, both withheld from the public.

The Bureau of Prisons (BOP) is withholding records related to an investigation into a suicide attempt and suicide at a federal prison under FOIA Exemption 7(E), which protects law enforcement techniques and procedures.

The withheld information includes details on Security Threat Group (STG) designations, emergency response steps in the Special Housing Unit, MCC investigatory sources and steps, After Action Review team procedures, and evidence storage locations.

The government argues that even if general suicide prevention techniques (like 'double-ceiling') are public, the specific application of investigatory techniques in this context is not, and its disclosure could help inmates circumvent BOP procedures.

The document is a legal filing dated January 15, 2021, arguing the court should grant the government's motion for summary judgment and deny the plaintiff's cross-motion, effectively blocking the release of the investigatory records.
